Key Findings

  • Blackpool Council's spending decreased by £79.1M (45.2%) from 2019 to 2026, with a total spend of £4068.9M across 630,914 transactions.
  • The largest year-over-year increase was £514.6M (92.0%) from 2023 to 2024, with a spend of £1074.2M in 2024.
  • The largest year-over-year decrease was £969,671,802 (91.0%) from 2025 to 2026, with a spend of £95.8M in 2026.
  • The council's spending increased by £133.9M (76.5%) from 2019 to 2020, with a spend of £308.8M in 2020.
  • The overall change in spending from 2019 to 2026 shows a significant fluctuation, with a peak spend of £1074.2M in 2024.

Introduction to Blackpool Council's Spending

Blackpool Council's spending data, covering the period from 2019/20 to 2025/26, provides valuable insights into the council's financial trajectory. With a total spend of £4068.9M across 630,914 transactions, the data reveals a complex pattern of increases and decreases in spending over the years.

The data shows that the council's spending increased significantly from 2019 to 2020, with a rise of £133.9M (76.5%). This increase was followed by more moderate growth in subsequent years, with a 25.0% increase from 2020 to 2021 and a 4.6% increase from 2021 to 2022.

However, the most notable increase in spending occurred from 2023 to 2024, with a 92.0% rise to £1074.2M. This significant increase was followed by a moderate decrease of 0.8% from 2024 to 2025, and a substantial decrease of 91.0% from 2025 to 2026.

Year-by-Year Spending Trends

The year-by-year spending trends reveal a fluctuating pattern, with significant increases and decreases over the years. The data shows that the council's spending peaked in 2024 at £1074.2M, followed by a decrease to £1065.5M in 2025 and a further decrease to £95.8M in 2026.

Conclusion and Implications

The analysis of Blackpool Council's spending data reveals a complex pattern of increases and decreases in spending over the years. The significant fluctuations in spending, particularly the substantial increase from 2023 to 2024 and the decrease from 2025 to 2026, raise important questions about the council's financial management and planning.

The data suggests that the council's spending is subject to significant variations, which may be influenced by a range of factors, including changes in government policies, economic conditions, and local priorities. Further analysis and investigation are needed to fully understand the underlying causes of these fluctuations and their implications for the council's financial sustainability.

What You Can Do

  • Submit a Freedom of Information request to Blackpool Council about the factors influencing the significant increase in spending from 2023 to 2024.
  • Attend Blackpool Council's committee meetings, which are open to the public, to learn more about the council's financial planning and decision-making processes.
  • Check the council's published contracts register to gain insight into the council's procurement practices and supplier relationships.
  • Write to your local councillor about your concerns regarding the council's financial management and the implications of the spending fluctuations for local services and communities.
  • Visit aidoge.co.uk to explore the full spending data and gain a deeper understanding of the council's financial activities and trends.
This article is based on Blackpool Council's published spending data covering 2019/20 to 2025/26. All figures are drawn directly from transactions published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Analysis by AI DOGE.
